Based on my search results, here's what I found about natural pause durations in speech editing and professional audio editing standards:

## Natural Pause Durations in Speech

### Standard Pause Values for Speech Timing

Every comma in text adds a brief hesitation (default 300 milliseconds), while periods, exclamation points, and question marks create longer natural breaks (default 700 milliseconds).(no content)This punctuation-aware calculation mirrors real speech patterns and provides significantly more accurate estimates than simple division.

### Text-to-Speech Standards

In text-to-speech synthesis, timing control ranges from 150ms to 5 seconds for natural speech flow.(no content)Default pauses such as 300ms between sentences and 400ms between paragraphs provide general timing, though these can be overridden in specific places.

### Research on Pause Perception

Research has evaluated listener perceptions of communicative effectiveness and likability of shorter pause lengths between 250 ms and one second.(no content)Recording and analyzing your own speeches reveals personal pause patterns—if you consistently take 900ms at periods rather than the 700ms default, updating this setting makes all future estimates more accurate.

### Types of Pauses in Natural Speech

There are three main categories of pauses: (1) regular natural pauses caused by respiration activity (breath pauses), (2) irregular intentional pauses purposely used as a stylistic form, especially by professional speakers (silent pauses), and (3) irregular, unintentional disfluencies from uncertainty, hesitations or short reflections.(no content)Professional speakers speak more slowly, with fewer disfluencies and formulate shorter sentences, making their speech more adjusted for efficient listening and understanding.

### Professional Audio Editing Considerations

When editing, you can zoom in to edit specific sections—for example, removing an awkward pause—and the timeline adapts, showing more granular details down to fractions of a second.(no content)In tools like Adobe Firefly, the default pause added is one second when creating pauses in generated speech.

### Speaking Rate Context

Speech rate in spontaneous monologues is about 117 words per minute. The mean length of a sentence (containing average 18 words) was about 10 seconds, while the mean length of a speech unit divided by punctuation (average 5 words) was 3.5 seconds.(no content)For voice-over work, typical speaking rates range between 130–180 words per minute, depending on tone and audience.

Here are the search results for podcast silence removal threshold settings in Descript, Audacity, and professional tools:

## Audacity Truncate Silence Settings

To be treated as silence in Audacity, the audio must be below a threshold level (measured in dB). If not enough silences are being reduced, increase the threshold to a higher (less negative) number.(no content)If there is noticeable background noise, you may need to set the threshold as a higher (less negative) value than the default. Silences are detected if they remain below the specified threshold for at least the specified time duration.

### Key Audacity Parameters:
- Audacity uses certain thresholds to decide what is silence: Min Duration, Max Duration, and Silence Threshold. These settings will decide what is considered silence and remove them.
- Silence Compression determines how much of the silence is removed. Instead of removing all silence, Audacity compresses it. For example, using 3:1 compression, a 3-second period of silence would be compressed down to 1 second.

### Practical Podcast Settings:
If a longer silence, like 2.1 or more seconds, is already recorded into your audio, you can use Truncate Silence to shorten everything longer than 2 seconds down to exactly two seconds. Set your min and max silences to 2000 ms and compression to 1:1. You may have to play with the threshold to find the right level for your background noise.(no content)One editor describes importing their podcast file into Audacity and running the truncate silence effect using 0.5 seconds, so all the silence is shortened to 0.5 seconds.

## Descript's Approach

Descript allows you to remove or trim unwanted gaps, word gaps, and pauses from audio and video. The best part is you choose how much dead air to keep so everything flows smoothly.(no content)Once uploaded, Descript will transcribe your file, showing any silences or pauses as gray bars.(no content)You can highlight and press backspace to remove or trim silences in both transcript and media. Or select Actions > Shorten word gaps to systematically cut silences from your audio at once or in steps. Descript also lets you fine-tune how sensitive the silence detection is, along with setting a default word gap length.(no content)Descript turns editing into a text experience where you can see silences right in your transcript and delete them like you're backspacing through a typo.

## Comparison & Professional Recommendations

Audacity's Truncate Silence effect lets you set precise thresholds for silence detection and removal. It's completely free and open-source with no watermarks or limitations, offering granular control over silence detection parameters.(no content)For podcasts or audio-only projects, Audacity might suffice. For an all-in-one solution that handles both audio and video with text-based editing, Descript offers the most intuitive experience.(no content)Professional editors develop content-specific templates and workflows that streamline the editing process while ensuring appropriate treatment for each content type. These templates include predetermined threshold and duration settings optimized for specific content categories, saving time while ensuring consistent results. However, templates serve as starting points rather than rigid rules, and experienced editors adjust settings based on the specific characteristics of each recording.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of film dialogue editing, pause duration, dramatic pauses vs. dead air, and broadcast standards:

## Dramatic Pause vs. Dead Air

The Dramatic Pause is a beat or two of silence with no dialogue and little or no music/background sound. Usually done to heighten the anticipation before a reveal.(no content)Also called a "Pregnant Pause", it can also follow the reveal when something is particularly shocking.(no content)Dead air, by contrast, is a gap caused by a gaffe – a miscalculation, a technical mistake, a brain freeze. A pause is intentional, dead air is accidental.(no content)Intentional silence has purpose and timing. Dead air has neither. A well-placed pause feels natural and meaningful, while dead air feels accidental and disruptive.

## Pause Duration Guidelines

A pause for effect is typically shorter, usually just 1 to 2 seconds.(no content)A reflective pause—which gives your audience time to think—can last from 3 to 7 seconds.

## The Role of Pacing in Film Editing

A lot of great editors believe pacing is managing and utilizing the space in a scene—space meaning dead air. Some of the greatest examples of pacing come from Quentin Tarantino. The pacing of the conversations in his films really sets the bar for pacing.(no content)Scenes can be masterpieces when it comes to pacing even when the pacing is very slow. Managing the space well, with long pauses between lines of dialogue, can feel just right.(no content)A large part of what editors do is controlling how the audience experiences the passage of time. Part of the reason why movies resonate with us is because they mimic and reflect how we experience time.

## Broadcast Standards for Dialogue

When mixing in a dub stage for theatrical, spoken dialogue should run around -10 to -12 dB, with very quiet whispers getting as far down as -20ish and screams hitting 0.(no content)If you are mixing for broadcast delivery, you need to get the channel/network specs and make it sound as good as possible within those specs.(no content)The American (ATSC A85) and European (EBU R128) specifications aim towards the film model of professionals mixing in calibrated environments by ear. These standards measure spectrum content and factor in RMS levels.(no content)In the broadcast world, level standards are fairly rigid with the 'dialog norm', which typically has a very narrow range with less dynamic range than theatrical because it's television.

## Technical Editing Tips

If you cut silence between lines, you may need to add matching room tone. Removing silence entirely can create unnatural shifts in background noise, especially when combining takes from different parts of a session. Room tone fills in the space and makes dialogue edits feel seamless.(no content)Tools like Reaper's Dynamic Split for bulk silence cuts and Auto Trim give editors control over silence thresholds and make it simple to prepare content for podcasts or broadcast delivery.

Based on my search, here's what I found about removing breath sounds from audio in podcast editing:

## Methods for Removing Breath Sounds

### Manual Editing Techniques
Manual editing is the most precise way to clean up breathing noises. It's best for short recordings, high-stakes projects, or situations where you can't risk removing parts of speech.

There are two main approaches:
- The two methods for removing sounds are DELETE and SILENCE. Most of the time, you will want to delete the 'um' because this is a pause used to search for a word.
- Silence, on the other hand, does not shorten the audio file length. It simply takes the existing sound and reduces it below hearing levels. Meaning it takes the breath and drops the portion of the file to zero dB or below. Since taking a breath to speak is natural, the silence leaves this natural break in the conversation intact.

### Using Plugins and Automation
When using breath control plugins, set detection sensitivity at a moderate setting so it catches breathing but not soft speech sounds like "h" or "f." A 40–70% reduction often keeps voices sounding natural while still cleaning the track.

### Pause Duration Control
BreathCut is designed to remove breathing sounds while maintaining natural speech rhythm and flow. Rather than creating abrupt cuts, the tool intelligently adjusts the timing to ensure your audio sounds professional and natural. You can also control the pause duration to match your preference.

### Noise Gate Settings
A noise gate opens and closes based on a threshold that is set allowing for the desired vocal passage to flow through while cutting off the undesired portion. Today's DAW (digital audio workstations) come equipped with plugins. Programs such as Audacity and Adobe Audition come stocked with noise gates. Next set the threshold, attack, release and noise floor.

### AI-Powered Tools
Several AI tools are available for automatic breath removal:
- Cleanvoice offers an AI-powered solution that detects and removes unwanted breathing sounds automatically. The AI can distinguish normal, expressive breathing sounds and heavy, distracting breaths. That way, you keep the ambiance without annoying your listeners.
- When Auphonic's "Remove Breathings" option is enabled, all the inhalation and exhalation sounds will be muted. They've also integrated the elimination of all types of mouth noises, such as smacking, chewing and clicking. These sounds are set to silence in your output file.

### Why Keep Natural Pauses
The more you sound like a human being, and not a machine, the easier dialogue is to understand. Breaths also act as a bit of a 'signpost'; intuitively the listener knows that there will be a short pause.

Here's what I found about silence detection threshold settings in professional audio editing:

## Silence Detection Threshold Settings

### Recommended Threshold Values

Professional silence management recommends starting with conservative settings around **-40 dB for speech content** and **-60 dB for music**, then adjusting based on your specific recording conditions.(no content)A good starting point for silence detection is **-30 dBFS**, though the right threshold depends on your audio source.

### Threshold Ranges in Popular Software

- **Audacity**: Threshold can take values between -20 dB and -80 dB.(no content)The default threshold for silence detection is set to -40 dB.

- **Adobe Audition**: Detects silences based on the threshold, where anything below the threshold is categorized as audio.

- **FireCut (Premiere Pro)**: You'll typically see two peaks in the audio analysis - useful audio around -20 dBFS and background noise around -50 dBFS. You should pick a threshold between these two values (such as -35 dBFS) so that the tool picks out only the portions below that threshold as silences.

### Important Considerations

Setting thresholds too aggressively (too high in negative dB values) can cause the tool to identify quiet speech or music as silence, leading to unwanted cuts in actual content. Conversely, setting thresholds too conservatively may miss obvious silences that should be removed.(no content)If there is noticeable background noise, you may need to set the threshold as a higher (less negative) value than the default.(no content)Since all normal signals are less than the full track height, the threshold will always be a negative number. Thus -40 dB is quieter than -30 dB, and -20 dB is higher (louder) than -30 dB.

### Duration Settings

For duration timing, use 1-2 second detection durations for speech content to preserve natural rhythm, and 0.5-1 second durations for music to maintain artistic timing.(no content)A good starting point for minimum silence duration is 750ms. Very small values are not recommended because they will create lots of small cuts even at breaks between words.

Based on my search, here's comprehensive information about silence detection and auto-cut parameters and thresholds for Adobe Premiere Pro:

## Silence Detection Parameters for Premiere Pro

### Key Parameters

**1. Silence Threshold (dB/dBFS)**
The Noise Level parameter defines what AutoCut considers a "silence." It's measured in decibels (dB) — any audio quieter than this threshold will be treated as silence.(no content)The threshold (in dBFS) determines the audio level below which tools consider as silence. A good starting point is -30 dBFS.

- Increase the threshold → removes more background noise. Lower it → keeps soft sounds like breathing or ambience.
- For most talking-head videos, a slightly higher threshold gives cleaner results.

**2. Minimum Silence Duration**
The minimum silence duration is the minimum duration for which your audio needs to be below the threshold in order to be detected as a silence portion that should be cut. While flexibility allows very small values, this is not recommended because it will create lots of small cuts even at breaks between words, which is usually undesirable. A good starting point is 750ms.

**3. Padding**
If you find that the silence detection was too "aggressive" (e.g., it's marked the start/ends of words as silences), this can be fixed by increasing padding.

### Additional Parameters (Filmora/Alternative Tools)
You can adjust audio parameters including: Volume Threshold, Minimum Duration, and Softening Buffer.

### Handling Options
AutoCut lets you decide what happens once silences are detected: Remove silences (deletes all silences completely), Keep silences (detects them but doesn't modify the audio), Mute silences (mutes audio during silent parts - ideal for noise cleanup), or Remove but keep spaces (cuts audio but preserves clip timing).(no content)Most editors use Mute silences for interviews and podcasts — it removes noise without shifting clips.

### Adobe Audition (Native Adobe Solution)
Based on your audio, the Deleting Silence effect auto detects the best decibel and time settings. You can still set the threshold manually if your workflow demands.(no content)The "Define Silence As" feature detects silences based on the threshold. Anything that is below the threshold is categorized as silence. Drag the "Signal is below" slider to set the decibel manually in dB, and drag the "For more than" slider to set the time in ms.

### Troubleshooting Tips
If "It cut out my entire sequence" → The detection threshold was too high / the tightness was too tight. Try Advanced mode with an auto-detected threshold (and move it lower if the suggested value seems too high), and set the min silence duration at least 750ms.

Based on the search results, I found information about film slates and clapperboards in the context of film production and editing. Here's what the search revealed:

The search returned one relevant result from FilmDaft about using film slates on set. The article covers various aspects of clapperboard usage in film production:

"A film slate is a labeled board with clap sticks that you place in front of the camera to identify each shot and create a clear sync point for picture and sound. You also see it called a clapperboard, clapper, or simply 'the slate.' When you use it correctly, you help your editor find the right take fast and keep picture, sound, and notes linked to the right scene."

Key points about slates and editing workflow:

- The slate labels the scene, shot, take, and roll so you always know which part of the script you shoot at that moment. It gives your film editor a clear clap that lines up picture and sound in the timeline.

- The 2nd Assistant Camera (2nd AC) is responsible for the clapperboard on set.

Regarding digital slate apps and features between takes:

- Many apps let you lock scene and roll fields so only the take number changes. This stops you from accidentally changing the scene number or roll between takes.

- It's smart to keep a clean slate between takes. A sponge and pens sit nearby, ready to wipe off old info and prepare for the next shot.

Here are the search results on speech pauses in linguistics and natural conversation:

## Overview of Speech Pauses in Linguistics

### Types of Pauses

Hesitation pauses are of various types. They are either silent pauses or filled pauses.(no content)Silent or unfilled pauses are breaks in the speech production and they differ in length, i.e., short or long.(no content)Filled pauses are defined by Crystal as "a term used by linguists to refer to non-silent pause that is to say hesitation which has been 'filled' by er, erm or some vocalization."

### Origins and Functions of Pauses

Considering the origin of pause usage, researchers mark out: (1) regular natural pauses caused by respiration activity (breath pauses), (2) irregular intentional pauses, purposely used as a stylistic form, especially by professional speakers (silent pauses), and (3) irregular, unintentional disfluencies, effects of uncertainty, hesitations or short reflections (acoustic events like silent pauses or filled pauses).(no content)Filled pauses (FPs) such as "uh" and "eh" signal disfluencies and can be classified into hesitations (FPHs) that are due to planning, control of turn taking, or speaker idiosyncrasies.

### Frequency in Natural Speech

At the rate of approximately 2–6 instances per 100 words, spontaneous speech contains linguistic elements which are not classically categorized as words or grammatical structures, but instead are variously labeled as interjection of sounds, hesitations, and disturbances.(no content)According to Starkweather (1980), fluency in speaking does not necessarily mean speech which is devoid of pauses. Rather, it means speaking with a reasonable number of pauses and hesitations that constitutes one of the features of natural conversation.

### Linguistic Functions

Speech pause is used by typical speakers to accomplish several linguistic functions. Firstly, syntactic boundaries can be marked by using speech pause at the end of a sentence, or even in between clauses.(no content)Filled pauses usually occur in important locations for planning, such as phrase boundaries, and utterances that are longer and more complex elicit more hesitations.

### Pause Duration Measurements

In some studies, 270 ms was used as the cut-off for the minimum pause length when analyzing speech pauses.

Research shows that filled pauses that were attached to a word on one side were the most frequent. Filled pauses occurring within a word and between two silent pauses were the longest of all.

### Individual and Contextual Variation

Depending on the speaker and situational/social context, pauses may be characterized by different properties. One factor is the type of personality of the speaker and their speaking habits. Another important factor is speaker preparation for the task, level of oratorical skills, and elocution abilities. Durations of pauses depend also on the kind of linguistic task. Stress during speaking is an important factor dictating the frequency and lengths of pauses.

### Evolution of Research Understanding

Early studies often categorized "um" and "uh" as involuntary noise, which was a result of speakers encountering language production problems rather than having much deliberate function or meaning attached to them.(no content)Even though early studies saw these types of linguistic elements as markers of hesitation or disfluency, more recent research has identified filled pauses as polyfunctional devices that can show both discourse-structuring and self-repairing uses.

content.text:
Based on my research, here is a comprehensive summary of natural pause detection standards for speech and dialogue editing:

---

## Natural Pause Detection in Speech/Dialogue Editing

### 1. Pause Duration Classifications

| Pause Type | Duration | Action |
|------------|----------|--------|
| **Micro-pause / Breath pause** | 150-300ms | Keep (natural speech rhythm) |
| **Comma pause / Word boundary** | 250-400ms | Keep (natural phrasing) |
| **Sentence pause** | 500-700ms | Keep (syntactic boundary) |
| **Paragraph/thought pause** | 700-1000ms | Keep (discourse structure) |
| **Dramatic pause** | 1-2 seconds | Keep (intentional effect) |
| **Reflective pause** | 3-7 seconds | Context-dependent (may keep for emphasis) |
| **Dead air / Mistakes** | >2 seconds (unintentional) | Cut |
| **Between-take silence** | >3-5 seconds | Cut |

### 2. Industry Standard Thresholds

**Silence Detection (dB thresholds):**
- Speech content: **-30 to -40 dBFS** (starting point)
- Clean recordings: **-40 dB** (Audacity default)
- Noisy recordings: **-20 to -30 dB** (higher threshold for background noise)
- Music: **-60 dB**

**Minimum Duration for Silence Cut:**
- Conservative: **750ms** (recommended starting point)
- Aggressive: **500ms** (may cut natural pauses)
- Very conservative: **2000ms** (only long gaps)

### 3. Differentiating Pause Types

**Dramatic Pauses (KEEP):**
- Duration: 1-2 seconds
- Characteristics: Intentional, preceded by complete thought, creates anticipation
- Context: Before reveals, after impactful statements
- Detection: Often follows complete sentences, speaker maintains engagement

**Breath Pauses (KEEP short ones):**
- Duration: 150-400ms
- Characteristics: Natural respiration, acts as "signpost" for listeners
- Recommendation: Silence (reduce to -inf dB) rather than delete
- Keep the timing, remove the noise

**Dead Air / Mistakes (CUT):**
- Duration: >2 seconds with no intentional purpose
- Characteristics: Accidental, brain freeze, technical issues
- Detection: Unplanned, disrupts flow, no artistic value
- Unlike dramatic pauses, lacks "purpose and timing"

**Between-Take Silence (CUT):**
- Duration: Typically 3-10+ seconds
- Characteristics: Complete silence or room tone only
- Detection: Often preceded by verbal markers ("cut", "again", clapper sounds)
- May contain slate/clapper audio signature

### 4. Configurable Parameters (Professional Tools)

**AutoCut / Premiere Pro Extensions:**
```
Noise Level Threshold: -30 to -40 dBFS
Minimum Silence Duration: 750ms (default)
Padding/Buffer: 50-150ms (prevents cutting word edges)
```

**Audacity Truncate Silence:**
```
Threshold: -40 dB (default, range -20 to -80)
Min Duration: 500-2000ms
Compression Ratio: 3:1 (shortens without removing)
```

**Breath Removal:**
```
Detection Sensitivity: 40-70% (moderate)
Reduction: 40-70% (not 100%, keeps naturalness)
```

### 5. Recommended Default Configuration for Splice

```typescript
const pauseDetectionConfig = {
  // Silence detection
  silenceThresholdDb: -35,           // dBFS, adjustable -20 to -50
  
  // Duration thresholds (milliseconds)
  minSilenceDuration: 750,           // Minimum to consider as silence
  naturalPauseMax: 1500,             // Keep pauses under this
  deadAirThreshold: 2500,            // Flag as potential cut above this
  betweenTakeThreshold: 5000,        // Likely between-take above this
  
  // Padding to prevent cutting word edges
  paddingMs: 100,                    // Buffer before/after cuts
  
  // Breath handling
  breathReduction: 0.6,              // 60% reduction (not full removal)
  keepBreathTiming: true,            // Silence but don't delete
  
  // Compression option (alternative to cutting)
  compressionRatio: 3,               // 3:1 shortens without jarring cuts
  maxCompressedSilence: 500,         // Target duration after compression
};
```

### 6. Key Insights from Research

1. **Linguistic research uses 270ms as minimum pause threshold** for speech analysis

2. **Filled pauses ("um", "uh") occur 2-6 times per 100 words** in natural speech - removing all creates unnatural audio

3. **Professional speakers have different pause patterns** than casual speakers - fewer disfluencies, shorter sentences

4. **Room tone matters**: When cutting silence, may need to fill with matching room tone to avoid jarring transitions

5. **Context is critical**: A 3-second pause in a dramatic scene is intentional; the same pause in a podcast interview is dead air

---

**Sources:**
- [Audacity Truncate Silence Manual](https://manual.audacityteam.org/man/truncate_silence.html)
